abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is assessed as
            satisfactory and project sustainability is considered
            likely. Both the World Bank and the Borrower have
            performances rated satisfactory overall. A key lesson of
            this project was the manner in which the World Bank and the
            Government responded to the post-war challenges facing the
            entire Rwandan portfolio, and this project in particular.
            The timely restructuring of the project in 1995 and 1997,
            together with other projects in the portfolio, and the
            Bank's flexibility in exercising its policies, helped
            restore project performance to satisfactory levels after two
            years of unsatisfactory ratings. Of great importance was the
            immediate shift in the Bank's overall assistance
            strategy to Rwanda. A related lesson was the readiness with
            which the new Government accepted existing national policies
            governing projects like this one. This factor helped
            consolidate donor confidence and support. Other lessons
            concerned the need to improve rural access both in terms of
            infrastructure and affordable motorized and non-motorized
            transport in order to promote higher productivity and
            increase incomes. Taking advantage of the very high
            population densities in rural areas and the very high
            occupancy of roadside land, road maintenance activities can
            easily be integrated into agricultural activities. Future
            projects in the sector should seek to establish partnerships
            with village communities and draw from this favorable
            environment for sustaining rural road maintenance.
